elements.content: The novel coordination polymers M­(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2Me2BPZ = 3,3′-dimethyl-1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole), M­(H2Me2BPZ)­(CH3COO)2­(H2O)2 (M = Co, Ni), and Cu­(H2Me2BPZ)­(Cl)2 were isolated along conventional or solvothermal routes. Their crystal structure was unveiled by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), while their thermal stability was assessed by coupling thermogravimetric analysis to variable-temperature PXRD. The textural properties of the M­(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn) compounds, featuring three-dimensional open frameworks with one-dimensional channels, were assessed by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively, and compared to those of the nonmethylated isostructural counterparts M­(BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2BPZ = 1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole). The positive effect of the methyl groups in CO2 adsorption, suggested by the adsorption energy trend [E ads(M­(Me2BPZ)) > E ads(M­(BPZ))] and substantiated by theoretical calculations at the B3LYP-D3 level coupled to topological analyses, is counterbalanced by the higher steric hindrance of Me2BPZ2– vs BPZ2–, finally reducing the amount of gas adsorbed by the M­(Me2BPZ) couple vs the M­(BPZ) one.

Their crystal structure was unveiled by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), while their thermal stability was assessed by coupling thermogravimetric analysis to variable-temperature PXRD. The textural properties of the M(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn) compounds, featuring three-dimensional open frameworks with one-dimensional channels, were assessed by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively, and compared to those of the nonmethylated isostructural counterparts M(BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2BPZ = 1H,1'H-4,4'-bipyrazole). The positive effect of the methyl groups in CO2 adsorption, suggested by the adsorption energy trend [E ads(M(Me2BPZ)) > E ads(M(BPZ))] and substantiated by theoretical calculations at the B3LYP-D3 level coupled to topological analyses, is counterbalanced by the higher steric hindrance of Me2BPZ2- vs BPZ2-, finally reducing the amount of gas adsorbed by the M(Me2BPZ) couple vs the M(BPZ) one.

elements.content: The vast fields of coordination polymers (CPs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been incessantly developing due to their potentiality in a wide range of key functional applications, spanning from luminescence to magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, gas storage, gas or liquid separation, drug delivery and imagingto mention only a few. CPs and MOFs are hybrid organic–inorganic compounds built up by metal ions or metal-containing clusters connected by poly­(topic) ligands within polymeric networks the topology, crystal structure, and functional behavior of which depend on the stereochemical requirements of the metal ion, as well as the hapticity, size, and functionalization of the ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The vast fields of coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been incessantly developing due to their potentiality in a wide range of key functional applications, spanning from luminescence to magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, gas storage, gas or liquid separation, drug delivery and imagingto mention only a few. CPs and MOFs are hybrid organic-inorganic compounds built up by metal ions or metal-containing clusters connected by poly(topic) ligands within polymeric networks the topology, crystal structure, and functional behavior of which depend on the stereochemical requirements of the metal ion, as well as the hapticity, size, and functionalization of the ligand.

elements.content: Poly­(azolate)-based spacers have gained increasing attention as an alternative to poly­(carboxylate)-based ones in the design and preparation of thermally stable, functional CPs and MOFs. In this context, we and others have contributed to the growth of the classes of poly­(pyrazolate)-based CPs and MOFs. After reporting on the M­(BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2BPZ = 1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole, ) and M­(Me4BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2Me4BPZ = 3,3′,5,5′tetramethyl-1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole, ) derivatives, we have focused the attention on the ligand 3,3′-dimethyl-1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole (H2Me2BPZ, ).

elements.content: Hereafter, we report on the synthesis and investigation of the structural aspects and thermal behavior of the coordination polymers M­(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn), M­(H2Me2BPZ)­(CH3COO)2­(H2O)2 (M = Co, Ni), and Cu­(H2Me2BPZ)­(Cl)2. Capture of carbon dioxide from anthropogenic emissions is one of the main challenges of current research at the academic and industrial level, as this greenhouse gas contributes more than 60% to global warming. CO2 capture and storage from exhausted gases by nanoporous adsorbents, such as MOFs, have been receiving remarkable consideration. In the light of this, the textural properties of the M­(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn) derivatives, featuring three-dimensional (3-D) open frameworks, were probed by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively, and compared to those of the non-methylated isostructural counterparts M­(BPZ) (M = Co, Zn), to shed light on the role of the −CH3 tags in the adsorption of CO2. Ab initio periodic calculations at the B3LYP-D3 level were carried out to complete the insight obtained by CO2 adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Hereafter, we report on the synthesis and investigation of the structural aspects and thermal behavior of the coordination polymers M(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn), M(H2Me2BPZ)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2 (M = Co, Ni), and Cu(H2Me2BPZ)(Cl)2. Capture of carbon dioxide from anthropogenic emissions is one of the main challenges of current research at the academic and industrial level, as this greenhouse gas contributes more than 60% to global warming. CO2 capture and storage from exhausted gases by nanoporous adsorbents, such as MOFs, have been receiving remarkable consideration. In the light of this, the textural properties of the M(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn) derivatives, featuring three-dimensional (3-D) open frameworks, were probed by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively, and compared to those of the non-methylated isostructural counterparts M(BPZ) (M = Co, Zn), to shed light on the role of the -CH3 tags in the adsorption of CO2. Ab initio periodic calculations at the B3LYP-D3 level were carried out to complete the insight obtained by CO2 adsorption.

elements.content: 3,3′-Dimethyl-1H,1H′-4,4′-bipyrazole (H2Me2BPZ) and 1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole (H2BPZ) were synthesized following the synthetic methodologies previously published by Sharko et al. and Boldog et al., respectively. All of the chemicals and reagents employed were purchased from commercial suppliers and used as received without further purification. All of the solvents were distilled prior to use. IR spectra were recorded as neat from 4000 to 600 cm–1 with a PerkinElmer Spectrum One System instrument. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed with a Fisons Instruments 1108 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under a N2 flow with a Perkin Pyris 1 thermal analyzer with heating rates in the range 5–10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) qualitative analyses were carried out with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (see for the instrument specifics), acquiring data at room temperature in the 3–35° 2θ range, with steps of 0.02°, and time per step of 1 s. The nature and purity of all the batches employed for the functional characterization were assessed by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and PXRD.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

3,3'-Dimethyl-1H,1H'-4,4'-bipyrazole (H2Me2BPZ) and 1H,1'H-4,4'-bipyrazole (H2BPZ) were synthesized following the synthetic methodologies previously published by Sharko et al. and Boldog et al., respectively. All of the chemicals and reagents employed were purchased from commercial suppliers and used as received without further purification. All of the solvents were distilled prior to use. IR spectra were recorded as neat from 4000 to 600 cm-1 with a PerkinElmer Spectrum One System instrument. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed with a Fisons Instruments 1108 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out under a N2 flow with a Perkin Pyris 1 thermal analyzer with heating rates in the range 5-10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) qualitative analyses were carried out with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (see  for the instrument specifics), acquiring data at room temperature in the 3-35° 2θ range, with steps of 0.02°, and time per step of 1 s. The nature and purity of all the batches employed for the functional characterization were assessed by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and PXRD.

elements.content: H2Me2BPZ (0.0324 g, 0.200 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF) (8 mL). Then, Co­(CH3COO)2­·4H2O (0.0498 g, 0.200 mmol) was added. The mixture was left under stirring in a high-pressure glass tube at 120 °C for 24 h, until a violet precipitate appeared. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with hot acetone (2 × 10 mL), and dried under vacuum. Yield: 86%. Co-Me 2 BPZ·S is insoluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), alcohols, acetone, acetonitrile (CH3CN), chlorinated solvents, and water. Elem. Anal. Calc. for C8H8CoN4·0.9­(C3H7NO) (fw = 284.89 g/mol): C, 44.97; H, 5.04; N, 24.01%. Found: C, 44.28; H, 4.68; N, 24.31%. IR (neat, cm–1): 2920 (vw) [ν­(C–Haliphatic)], 1674 (vs) [ν­(CO)], 1506 (m) [ν­(CC + CN)], 1443 (m), 1383 (w), 1345 (s), 1276 (m), 1097 (vs), 1060 (w), 994 (w), 969 (s), 824 (m). Co-Me 2 BPZ·S may be isolated also by using Co­(NO3)2·6H2O in either solvothermal conditions or methanol at 100 °C for 1 day in the presence of aq. KOH (0.4 mmol).

Synthesis of Zn(BPZ) (Zn-BPZ)

 Zn-BPZ was synthesized following a previously published synthetic path, namely, H2BPZ (0.0268 g, 0.200 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (30 mL). Then, sodium methoxide (0.0216 g, 0.4 mmol) was added. After 1/2 h warming at 45 °C with concomitant stirring, Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.0438 g, 0.200 mmol) was added. The mixture was left under stirring at room temperature for 24 h. A white precipitate was obtained, filtered off, washed with hot CH3OH (2 × 10 mL), and dried under vacuum. Yield: 72%. Elem. Anal. Calc. for C6H4N4Zn (fw = 197.51 g/mol): C, 36.49; H, 2.04; N, 28.37%. Found: C, 36.33; H, 2.21; N, 27.84%. IR (neat, cm-1): 3094 (vw) [ν(C-Haromatic)], 1519 (m) [ν(CC + CN)], 1447 (m), 1386 (s), 1291 (w), 1265 (s), 1166 (br,s), 1054 (s), 1016 (m), 917 (s), 829 (s).

elements.content: Microcrystalline powders of Co-Me 2 BPZ·S, Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S, Co–H 2 Me 2 BPZ, Ni–H 2 Me 2 BPZ, and Cu–H 2 Me 2 BPZ were deposited in the hollow of a silicon zero-background plate 0.2 mm deep (supplied by Assing Srl, Monterotondo, Italy). Data acquisitions were performed on a vertical-scan Bruker AXS D8 Advance θ:θ diffractometer, equipped with a Bruker Lynxeye linear position-sensitive detector, a Cu X-ray tube (λ = 1.5418 Å), primary beam Soller slits (2.5°), divergence slit (1 mm), antiscatter slit (8 mm), a filter of nickel in the diffracted beam. The generator was set at 40 kV and 40 mA. After preliminary acquisitions for fingerprinting analysis, typically performed in the 3–35° 2θ range, diffraction data-sets for structure determination were collected up to 105° 2θ, with steps of 0.02°, with an overall scan time of approximately 12 h. A standard peak search, followed by profile fitting, enabled us to estimate the low-to-medium-angle peak maximum positions which, through the Singular Value Decomposition algorithm implemented in TOPAS-R, provided approximate unit cell parameters for all the compounds. Space groups were assigned based on the observed systematic absences. For Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S, indexing suggested a unit cell of tetragonal metrics (Co-Me 2 BPZ·S: a = 8.91 Å, c = 7.45 Å, V = 591.9 Å3; Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S: a = 8.92 Å, c = 7.44 Å, V = 591.5 Å3), as in the case of the M-BPZ (M = Co, Zn) analogues. No structure solution was found in the tetragonal P space groups compatible with the systematic absences, nor in the isomorphic orthorhombic subgroup Cccm. Only decreasing the symmetry down to monoclinic C2/c granted us a successful structure determination. Structure solutions were performed with TOPAS-R by a combined Monte Carlo/Simulated Annealing approach using a rigid body to describe the crystallographically independent portion of the ligand, letting the position of its center of mass and its orientation (when allowed by symmetry) to be refined. The rigid body was built up through the Z-matrix formalism, assigning average values to bond distances and angles. For Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S a rigid body was used also to model DMF which, in both cases, was found disordered within the channels. In all the cases, a model with positional disorder affecting the methyl groups on the positions 3 and 5 of the penta-atomic ring was adopted during the structure refinement, carried out with the Rietveld method. The introduction of disorder affecting the methyl groups was found beneficial for the refinement (as witnessed by the lowering of R wp) in the case of Cu–H 2 Me 2 BPZ. For the other compounds, a 100% occupancy factor for one of the (3 or 5) positions was eventually adopted. The background was modeled by a polynomial function of the Chebyshev type, while peak profiles were described through the Fundamental Parameters Approach. A spherical harmonics description of the anisotropic peak broadening was necessary for all the compounds. In the case of Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S even the use of spherical harmonics was not completely satisfactory to model the strong anisotropy of the peak shapes, which could be due to paracrystallinity. A common, refined isotropic thermal factor (B iso) was attributed to all atoms, except to the metal and chloride ions, to which the isotropic thermal factor B iso(M, Cl) = B iso – 2.0 (Å2) was assigned. A correction for preferred orientation was applied, adopting the March-Dollase model, for Ni–H 2 Me 2 BPZ along the [001] direction. The final Rietveld refinement plots are shown in Figures S1 and S2 of the Supporting Information.

elements.content: To complement the thermogravimetric analyses, the thermal behavior of Co-Me 2 BPZ·S, Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S, Co–H 2 Me 2 BPZ, Ni–H 2 Me 2 BPZ, and Cu–H 2 Me 2 BPZ was investigated in situ and operando by variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction. As a general procedure, using a custom-made sample heater (Officina Elettrotecnica di Tenno, Ponte Arche, Italy), 20-mg samples of as-synthesized compounds were heated in air from 30 °C up to decomposition, with steps of 20 °C; a PXRD pattern was acquired at each step, covering a sensible low-to-medium-angle 2θ range. Treating the data acquired before loss of crystallinity by means of Le Bail parametric refinements enabled us to disclose the behavior of the unit cell parameters as a function of the temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Variable-Temperature Powder X-ray Diffraction (VT-PXRD)

To complement the thermogravimetric analyses, the thermal behavior of Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S, Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S, Co-H  2  Me  2  BPZ, Ni-H  2  Me  2  BPZ, and Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ was investigated in situ and operando by variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction. As a general procedure, using a custom-made sample heater (Officina Elettrotecnica di Tenno, Ponte Arche, Italy), 20-mg samples of as-synthesized compounds were heated in air from 30 °C up to decomposition, with steps of 20 °C; a PXRD pattern was acquired at each step, covering a sensible low-to-medium-angle 2θ range. Treating the data acquired before loss of crystallinity by means of Le Bail parametric refinements enabled us to disclose the behavior of the unit cell parameters as a function of the temperature.

elements.content: Specific surface area and pore texture of the M-BPZ and M-Me 2 BPZ (M = Co, Zn) MOFs were estimated by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively. Adsorption isotherms were measured by the volumetric method with a Quantachrome Autosorb 1 instrument. Batches of ca. 50 mg of as-synthesized materials were introduced into preweighed analysis tubes and outgassed overnight at 110 °C under high vacuum (nominally 10–6 mbar) before running the adsorption experiments. The two probes we adopted are complementary and allow analyzing different ranges of porosity: CO2 adsorption is used to assess the narrower microporosity (mean micropore width L 0 < 0.7 nm), where N2 adsorption can be kinetically restricted. On the contrary, according to the Gurvitch rule the volume of N2 adsorbed at the relative pressure of 0.95 (W 0.95) is a measure of both the micro- and mesopore volumes, provided that there are no constrictions at the micropore entrance. Hence, W 0.95 is considered as the total pore volume, and the volume of N2 adsorbed within the relative pressure range of 0.40–0.95 is considered as the mesopore volume. BJH and NL-DFT are the most commonly applied methods to determine pore size distribution (PSD). In the present work, NL-DFT was employed to determine the PSD of M-BPZ and M-Me 2 BPZ, as it was suggested to provide accurate results in MOFs textural characterization. The specific surface areas were obtained through the BET method by fitting the N2-adsorption data at low relative pressures (P/P 0 < 0.35). The Dubinin-Raduskevich equation () was used to fit both N2 and CO2 isotherms: W = W 0 exp [ − ( A β E a d s ) n ] where W is the amount of gas absorbed at the relative pressure P/P 0; W 0 is the limiting amount filling the micropores; A is the differential molar work given by A = RT lnP 0/P; β is the affinity coefficient (0.33 and 0.35 for N2 and CO2, respectively); E ads is the characteristic adsorption energy. N2 and CO2 molar volumes were taken as 34.65 and 43.01 cm3/mol, respectively. Once E ads was known, the mean micropore width, L 0, was obtained by applying the Stoeckli equation (): L 0 ( n m ) = 10.8 E a d s ( k J m o l − 1 ) − 11.4 which is valid for E ads values between 42 and 20 kJ/mol, corresponding to pore widths between 0.35 and 1.3 nm.

elements.content: The Zn-BPZ and M-Me 2 BPZ MOFs (M = Co, Zn) were characterized by means of ab initio calculations performed with the quantum-mechanics code CRYSTAL14, which solves the Schrödinger equation for periodic systems in a basis set of localized atomic orbitals. Neglecting the clathrated solvent, the Becke–Lee–Yang–Parr (B3LYP) hybrid functional was adopted to perform the full geometry optimization of the crystal structure and calculate charge density. In the subsequent study of CO2 diffusion into the channels, for a reliable estimate of the dispersive contributions to the binding energy the D3 a posteriori correction, originally proposed by Grimme and implemented in the CRYSTAL code (B3LYP-D3), was exploited. Atoms were described with all electrons basis sets of 6-21* quality, and the counterpoise method was used to correct the binding energy for the basis set superposition error. The Pack-Monkhorst/Gilat shrinking factors for the k-point sampling of the reciprocal space were set to 4, corresponding to 24 points at which the Hamiltonian matrix was diagonalized. The accuracy of the integral calculations was increased by setting the five tolerances to 7, 7, 7, 10, and 20. The adsorption energy, E ads, was calculated at the B3LYP-D3 level according to the formula: E a d s = [ ( E ( n C O 2 @ M O F ) − E ( M O F ) − n × E ( C O 2 ) n ) ] where E(nCO2@MOF), E(MOF), and E(CO2) are the total energies of the MOFs with and without CO2, and of carbon dioxide in the gas phase, respectively, and n corresponds to the number of CO2 molecules per cell. Standard enthalpies, H(T), at 0 and 298 K were calculated as follows: H ( T ) = E + E Z P E + E T + P × V by adding at the pressure per volume term the zero-point (E ZPE) and thermal (E T) energy contributions arising from the analysis of the nuclear motion. The heat of adsorption, H ads(T), was then estimated with the same formula reported in by substituting E(nCO2@MOF), E(MOF), E(CO2) with H(nCO2@MOF), H­(MOF), H(CO2), respectively. Complete phonon frequencies, at the k = 0 Γ point, were computed within the harmonic approximation by diagonalizing the mass-weighted Hessian matrix, and the host–guest interactions were characterized by exploiting the potentiality of Bader topological analysis of the electron density, as implemented in the TOPOND program incorporated in CRYSTAL14.

Theoretical Calculations

The Zn-BPZ  and M-Me  2  BPZ MOFs (M = Co, Zn) were characterized by means of ab initio calculations performed with the quantum-mechanics code CRYSTAL14, which solves the Schrödinger equation for periodic systems in a basis set of localized atomic orbitals. Neglecting the clathrated solvent, the Becke-Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) hybrid functional was adopted to perform the full geometry optimization of the crystal structure and calculate charge density. In the subsequent study of CO2 diffusion into the channels, for a reliable estimate of the dispersive contributions to the binding energy the D3 a posteriori correction, originally proposed by Grimme and implemented in the CRYSTAL code (B3LYP-D3), was exploited. Atoms were described with all electrons basis sets of 6-21* quality, and the counterpoise method was used to correct the binding energy for the basis set superposition error. The Pack-Monkhorst/Gilat shrinking factors for the k-point sampling of the reciprocal space were set to 4, corresponding to 24 points at which the Hamiltonian matrix was diagonalized. The accuracy of the integral calculations was increased by setting the five tolerances to 7, 7, 7, 10, and 20. The adsorption energy, E ads, was calculated at the B3LYP-D3 level according to the formula: 3      E   a d s   =  [  (   E  ( n C   O   2   @ M O F )  - E  ( M O F )  - n × E  ( C   O   2   )    n   )  ]    where E(nCO2@MOF), E(MOF), and E(CO2) are the total energies of the MOFs with and without CO2, and of carbon dioxide in the gas phase, respectively, and n corresponds to the number of CO2 molecules per cell. Standard enthalpies, H(T), at 0 and 298 K were calculated as follows: 4    H  ( T )  = E +   E   Z P E   +   E   T   + P × V   by adding at the pressure per volume term the zero-point (E ZPE) and thermal (E T) energy contributions arising from the analysis of the nuclear motion. The heat of adsorption, H ads(T), was then estimated with the same formula reported in  by substituting E(nCO2@MOF), E(MOF), E(CO2) with H(nCO2@MOF), H(MOF), H(CO2), respectively. Complete phonon frequencies, at the k = 0 Γ point, were computed within the harmonic approximation by diagonalizing the mass-weighted Hessian matrix, and the host-guest interactions were characterized by exploiting the potentiality of Bader topological analysis of the electron density, as implemented in the TOPOND program incorporated in CRYSTAL14.

elements.content: The MOFs M-Me 2 BPZ·S (M = Zn and Co; S = solvent) can be isolated in good yields, as microcrystalline powders, along both conventional and solvothermal synthetic routes. Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S can be isolated by using Zn­(CH3COO)2­·2H2O as the source of zinc­(II) ions in the presence of water, at room temperature. Alternatively, it can be prepared in DMF, in solvothermal conditions, by employing either Zn­(CH3COO)2­·2H2O, or other ZnX2 salts (X = NO3 – or ClO4 –). Co-Me 2 BPZ·S can be prepared in DMF, in solvothermal conditions, by using Co­(CH3COO)2­·4H2O or Co­(NO3)2­·6H2O. Alternatively, it can be obtained by gentle warming of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O and the ligand in methanol in the presence of a base. Worthy of note, due to the higher solubility of H2Me2BPZ vs H2BPZ in DMF imparted by the methyl groups, a lower amount of solvent is necessary to isolate the methylated MOFs (see the ). With reference to the batches isolated in DMF, IR spectroscopy purports the presence of clathrated solvent: the bands centered at 1673 and 1674 cm–1 in the spectra of Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S and Co-Me 2 BPZ·S, respectively, can be ascribed to the CO stretching of DMF. The absence of N–H stretching bands indicates the formation of Me2BPZ2– dianions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Preliminary Characterization

The MOFs M-Me  2  BPZ⋅S (M = Zn and Co; S = solvent) can be isolated in good yields, as microcrystalline powders, along both conventional and solvothermal synthetic routes. Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S can be isolated by using Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O as the source of zinc(II) ions in the presence of water, at room temperature. Alternatively, it can be prepared in DMF, in solvothermal conditions, by employing either Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, or other ZnX2 salts (X = NO3 - or ClO4 -). Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S can be prepared in DMF, in solvothermal conditions, by using Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O or Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Alternatively, it can be obtained by gentle warming of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and the ligand in methanol in the presence of a base. Worthy of note, due to the higher solubility of H2Me2BPZ vs H2BPZ in DMF imparted by the methyl groups, a lower amount of solvent is necessary to isolate the methylated MOFs (see the ). With reference to the batches isolated in DMF, IR spectroscopy purports the presence of clathrated solvent: the bands centered at 1673 and 1674 cm-1 in the spectra of Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S, respectively, can be ascribed to the CO stretching of DMF. The absence of N-H stretching bands indicates the formation of Me2BPZ2- dianions.

elements.content: In the absence of a base along a conventional route, reacting M­(II) acetates (M = Co, Ni) with H2Me2BPZ in methanol, at room temperature, yielded the compounds M­(H2Me2BPZ)­(CH3COO)2­(H2O)2 (M-H 2 Me 2 BPZ). IR spectroscopy suggests the presence of neutral ligands and water (N–H and O–H stretching bands in the range 3384–3336 cm–1 and 2617–2620 cm–1, respectively). Moreover, the two strong bands peaked at 1564 cm–1 and 1398–1403 cm–1 correspond to the asymmetric (νa) and symmetric (νs) stretching modes of the acetate anion, respectively. Their difference, Δν = νa – νs = 166–161 cm–1, likely indicates a bridging coordination mode.

IR spectroscopy suggests the presence of neutral ligands and water (N-H and O-H stretching bands in the range 3384-3336 cm-1 and 2617-2620 cm-1, respectively). Moreover, the two strong bands peaked at 1564 cm-1 and 1398-1403 cm-1 correspond to the asymmetric (νa) and symmetric (νs) stretching modes of the acetate anion, respectively. Their difference, Δν = νa - νs = 166-161 cm-1, likely indicates a bridging coordination mode.

elements.content: Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c and are isostructural. The asymmetric unit contains one M­(II) ion (M = Co, Zn) and one Me2BPZ2– dianion, both in special positions. Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S are isoreticular to the two couples of MOFs M-BPZ (M = Co, Zn; H2BPZ = 1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole), crystallizing in the tetragonal space group P42/mmc, and M-Me 4 BPZ (M = Co, Zn; H2Me4BPZ = 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethyl-1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole), crystallizing in the tetragonal space group P–42c. Hence, Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S feature a (4,4)-connected 3-D porous network of PtS topology. Tetrahedral M­(II) ions, coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of four Me2BPZ2– ligands, [Co–N distances 2.004(7) and 2.149(7) Å, N–Co–N angles in the range 96.6(4)° to 120.9(7)°; Zn–N distances 2.042(4) and 2.212(4) Å, N–Zn–N angles in the range 88.0(3)° to 112.05(8)°] act as nodes, while N,N′N″,N‴-exo-tetradentate ligands act as spacers (). One-dimensional (1-D) channels running parallel to the [001] direction are present. The walls of the channels are decorated by the ligands, which keep the nodes, occupying the vertices, at a distance of 8.914(9) Å (M = Co) or 8.918(7) Å (M = Zn). The channels have a rhombic shape (diagonals of 12.581(2) and 12.632(1) Å for M = Co, 12.608(3) and 12.615(3) Å for M = Zn) and account, at ambient conditions, for an empty volume of ∼38%. As expected, the empty volume and channel size decrease with the trend M-Me 4 BPZ < M-Me 2 BPZ < M-BPZ (): worthy of note, the size of the channels is affected in a more incisive manner upon passing from M-Me 2 BPZ to M-Me 4 BPZ, than from M-BPZ to M-Me 2 BPZ: In the case of the M-BPZ and M-Me 2 BPZ compounds, the ligand is planar; at variance, in M-Me 4 BPZ, the steric hindrance of the methyl groups forces the torsion angle about the C–C exocyclic bond to be higher than 70°. As the empty volume decreases by only 4% on passing from M-BPZ to M-Me 2 BPZ and by 26% on passing from M-BPZ to M-Me 4 BPZ, for the functional characterization we compared the performance of the M-Me 2 BPZ MOFs only to that of the M-BPZ MOFs. Incidentally, in both Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S the methyl groups are ordered in one of the two possible positions (3 or 5) of the pyrazolate rings. The reader is addressed to for experimental details.

Crystal Structure Analysis

Crystal and Molecular Structure of Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S 

 Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/c and are isostructural. The asymmetric unit contains one M(II) ion (M = Co, Zn) and one Me2BPZ2- dianion, both in special positions. Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S are isoreticular to the two couples of MOFs M-BPZ  (M = Co, Zn; H2BPZ = 1H,1'H-4,4'-bipyrazole), crystallizing in the tetragonal space group P42/mmc, and M-Me  4  BPZ  (M = Co, Zn; H2Me4BPZ = 3,3',5,5'-tetramethyl-1H,1'H-4,4'-bipyrazole), crystallizing in the tetragonal space group P-42c. Hence, Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S feature a (4,4)-connected 3-D porous network of PtS topology. Tetrahedral M(II) ions, coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of four Me2BPZ2- ligands, [Co-N distances 2.004(7) and 2.149(7) Å, N-Co-N angles in the range 96.6(4)° to 120.9(7)°; Zn-N distances 2.042(4) and 2.212(4) Å, N-Zn-N angles in the range 88.0(3)° to 112.05(8)°] act as nodes, while N,N'N",N‴-exo-tetradentate ligands act as spacers (). One-dimensional (1-D) channels running parallel to the [001] direction are present. The walls of the channels are decorated by the ligands, which keep the nodes, occupying the vertices, at a distance of 8.914(9) Å (M = Co) or 8.918(7) Å (M = Zn). The channels have a rhombic shape (diagonals of 12.581(2) and 12.632(1) Å for M = Co, 12.608(3) and 12.615(3) Å for M = Zn) and account, at ambient conditions, for an empty volume of ~38%. As expected, the empty volume and channel size decrease with the trend M-Me  4  BPZ < M-Me  2  BPZ < M-BPZ (): worthy of note, the size of the channels is affected in a more incisive manner upon passing from M-Me  2  BPZ to M-Me  4  BPZ, than from M-BPZ to M-Me  2  BPZ: In the case of the M-BPZ and M-Me  2  BPZ compounds, the ligand is planar; at variance, in M-Me  4  BPZ, the steric hindrance of the methyl groups forces the torsion angle about the C-C exocyclic bond to be higher than 70°. As the empty volume decreases by only 4% on passing from M-BPZ to M-Me  2  BPZ and by 26% on passing from M-BPZ to M-Me  4  BPZ, for the functional characterization we compared the performance of the M-Me  2  BPZ MOFs only to that of the M-BPZ MOFs. Incidentally, in both Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S the methyl groups are ordered in one of the two possible positions (3 or 5) of the pyrazolate rings. The reader is addressed to  for experimental details.

Co-H 2 Me 2 BPZ and Ni-H 2 Me 2 BPZ crystallize in the monoclinic space group C2/m and are isostructural. In the crystal structure, the metal center lays on a 2/m symmetry element, both the ligands on mirror planes, and the water molecule on a 2-fold axis, this making the asymmetric unit one-fourth of the formula unit. The metal ions show an octahedral coordination sphere of the type trans-MN2O4 defined by the nitrogen atoms of two crystallographically equivalent H2Me2BPZ ligands, one oxygen atom of two equivalent κ1O-acetate anions, and the oxygen atoms of two equivalent water molecules occupying the apical positions (a) [Co–Owater 2.051(8) Å, Co–Oacetate 2.132(5) Å, Co–N 2.126(6) Å; Ni–Owater 2.02(1) Å, Ni–Oacetate 2.02(6) Å, Ni–N 2.100(2) Å]. N,N′-exo-bidentate H2Me2BPZ ligands bridge adjacent metal centers along 1-D linear chains running parallel to the [001] direction (the bridged M···M distance is equal to the length of the c-axis) (a). The N1–H hydrogen atom of H2Me2BPZ is involved in an intramolecular hydrogen bond with the uncoordinated oxygen atom (O11) of an adjacent acetate ligand [b; N1 and O11i: N···O 2.595(9) Å, N–H···O 176.7(8)° for Co-H 2 Me 2 BPZ; N···O 2.595(8) Å, N–H···O 168.8(7)° for Ni-H 2 Me 2 BPZ; symmetry code: (i) −x, −y, −z]. O11 also behaves as a hydrogen bond acceptor toward two crystallographically equivalent water molecules of neighboring metal chains [O1W and O11ii/iii: O···O 2.802(7) Å, O–H···O 171.3(2)° for Co-H 2 Me 2 BPZ; O···O 2.893(9) Å, O–H···O 169.3(2)° for Ni-H 2 Me 2 BPZ; symmetry codes: (ii) −1/2 + x, 1/2 – y, z; (iii) 1/2 – x, 1/2 – y, z]: a graph set motif of the type R 2 4(8) can be envisaged (highlighted in green in b). These features are in accordance with the bridging coordination mode suggested by IR spectroscopy for the acetate anion (see ). Overall, Co-H 2 Me 2 BPZ and Ni-H 2 Me 2 BPZ can be classified as 3-D hybrid coordination/hydrogen bonded polymers. At ambient conditions, no empty volume is present.

elements.content: Cu-H 2 Me 2 BPZ crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit comprises one Cu­(II) metal center and one H2Me2BPZ ligand, both laying on crystallographic inversion centers, and one chloride anion, on a general position. The metal centers show a square planar geometry of the type trans-CuCl2N2 (a) [Cu–Cl 2.309(5) Å, Cu–N 2.084(3) Å, N–Cu–Cl 90.0(3)°]. The ligand bridges two metal centers 9.8270(5) Å apart, forming a 1-D coordination polymer (b) running parallel to the [011] direction of the unit cell. The polymer is almost planar, with the heavy atoms laying in the (1 1̅ 1) plane [highest deviation from the (1 1̅ 1) plane 2.3 Å for Cl1]. The N–H groups of the ligand are involved in hydrogen bonds with the chlorine atoms coordinated to the same metal center (b) [N1···Cl1 2.968(5) Å, N1–H···Cl 120.4(5)°]. Finally, along the [100] direction adjacent polymeric chains interact through π–π stacking between the pyrazole rings [a; distance between centroids 3.8821(2) Å]. At ambient conditions, no empty volume is present.

Crystal and Molecular Structure of Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ 

 Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit comprises one Cu(II) metal center and one H2Me2BPZ ligand, both laying on crystallographic inversion centers, and one chloride anion, on a general position. The metal centers show a square planar geometry of the type trans-CuCl2N2 (a) [Cu-Cl 2.309(5) Å, Cu-N 2.084(3) Å, N-Cu-Cl 90.0(3)°]. The ligand bridges two metal centers 9.8270(5) Å apart, forming a 1-D coordination polymer (b) running parallel to the [011] direction of the unit cell. The polymer is almost planar, with the heavy atoms laying in the (1 1̅ 1) plane [highest deviation from the (1 1̅ 1) plane 2.3 Å for Cl1]. The N-H groups of the ligand are involved in hydrogen bonds with the chlorine atoms coordinated to the same metal center (b) [N1⋅⋅⋅Cl1 2.968(5) Å, N1-H⋅⋅⋅Cl 120.4(5)°]. Finally, along the [100] direction adjacent polymeric chains interact through π-π stacking between the pyrazole rings [a; distance between centroids 3.8821(2) Å]. At ambient conditions, no empty volume is present.

elements.content: According to their TGA traces (), the two compounds M-Me 2 BPZ·S (M = Co, Zn) are stable, under N2, up to ∼340 and 460 °C, respectively. Loss of clathrated solvent is denounced, below 200 °C, by weight losses of ∼24% and ∼23%, corresponding to ∼1 and ∼0.9 mol of DMF per formula unit (f.u.) for Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S, respectively (calculated losses 25.0 and 24.4%, respectively). As assessed by in situ and operando VT-PXRD (a,b), solvent loss is not accompanied by loss of crystallinity. As highlighted by a Le Bail parametric treatment of the data (c,d), solvent loss brings about a unit cell volume shrinkage in both compounds. However, the variation in volume has a different trend in the two cases. Zn-Me 2 BPZ shows a step-like decrease of ∼0.8% between 130 and 210 °C, mainly related with the shrinkage of the c-axis. On the other hand, Co-Me 2 BPZ shows a smooth decrease of ∼ −1.3% in the temperature range 30–330 °C, related with the decrease of the b- and c-axes. Above 350 °C, both compounds start suffering from loss of crystallinity.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

Thermal Behavior of Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S. 

According to their TGA traces (), the two compounds M-Me  2  BPZ⋅S (M = Co, Zn) are stable, under N2, up to ~340 and 460 °C, respectively. Loss of clathrated solvent is denounced, below 200 °C, by weight losses of ~24% and ~23%, corresponding to ~1 and ~0.9 mol of DMF per formula unit (f.u.) for Co-Me  2  BPZ⋅S and Zn-Me  2  BPZ⋅S, respectively (calculated losses 25.0 and 24.4%, respectively). As assessed by in situ and operando VT-PXRD (a,b), solvent loss is not accompanied by loss of crystallinity. As highlighted by a Le Bail parametric treatment of the data (c,d), solvent loss brings about a unit cell volume shrinkage in both compounds. However, the variation in volume has a different trend in the two cases. Zn-Me  2  BPZ shows a step-like decrease of ~0.8% between 130 and 210 °C, mainly related with the shrinkage of the c-axis. On the other hand, Co-Me  2  BPZ shows a smooth decrease of ~ -1.3% in the temperature range 30-330 °C, related with the decrease of the b- and c-axes. Above 350 °C, both compounds start suffering from loss of crystallinity.

elements.content: According to their TGA traces (), the two compounds M-H 2 Me 2 BPZ are stable, under N2, only up to ∼125 °C (M = Co) and 70 °C (M = Ni). The ∼30% weight loss observed in the TGA trace of Co-H 2 Me 2 BPZ in the temperature range 125–175 °C is in agreement with the release of two molecules of acetic acid per f.u. (theoretical loss 32%). The weight loss of ∼10% observed in the range 200–400 °C can be assigned to the loss of two molecules of water per f.u. (theoretical loss 9.6%). Ni-H 2 Me 2 BPZ undergoes three consecutive mass losses, namely, 10% (70–150 °C), 20% (150–250 °C), and 10% (250–400 °C), overall corresponding to the loss of two molecules of acetic acid and two molecules of water per f.u. (theoretical loss 41.6%). VT-PXRD (Figure S3a,b of the SI) confirms the limited thermal robustness of the two materials and highlights that no phase change takes place before the first weight loss, which is accompanied by loss of crystallinity (observed starting from 150 °C for both compounds). A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data before loss of crystallinity enabled us to highlight that while the a- and c-axes undergo negligible variations in the temperature range 30–150 °C (Figure S3c,d of the SI), the b-axis is affected by a slightly higher variation, increasing by 0.8%, with a concomitant increase of the unit cell volume amounting to 0.8% (M = Co) or 0.9% (M = Ni) in the same temperature range. The slight increase of the b-axis is reasonably promoted by a weakening of the interchain hydrogen bond interactions existing, at room temperature, along the [010] direction (b). At least in the conditions essayed for the VT-PXRD experiments, loss of coordinated acetic acid and water molecules does not bring about the formation of microcrystalline homoleptic compounds of formula M­(Me2BPZ), as observed in the past for Zn­(CH3COO)­(pz)­(Hpz).

elements.content: According to its TGA trace () Cu-H 2 Me 2 BPZ decomposes starting from ∼280 °C. VT-PXRD (Figure S4a in the SI) confirms this evidence also in air and highlights that no phase change takes place before loss of crystallinity is observed (∼330 °C). A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data reveals (Figure S4b in the SI) that the unit cell axis undergoing the highest variation is the a-axis (increasing by 2.2% in the temperature range 30–330 °C), this occurrence suggesting a weakening of the π–π interactions along the [100] direction (a). Because of thermal expansion, the unit cell volume increases by 2.3%.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior of Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ 

According to its TGA trace () Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ decomposes starting from ~280 °C. VT-PXRD (Figure S4a in the SI) confirms this evidence also in air and highlights that no phase change takes place before loss of crystallinity is observed (~330 °C). A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data reveals (Figure S4b in the SI) that the unit cell axis undergoing the highest variation is the a-axis (increasing by 2.2% in the temperature range 30-330 °C), this occurrence suggesting a weakening of the π-π interactions along the [100] direction (a). Because of thermal expansion, the unit cell volume increases by 2.3%.

elements.content: The N2 adsorption isotherms measured for the MOFs M-BPZ and M-Me 2 BPZ at 77 K are depicted in a,b, while the results obtained from their analysis by applying the DR and NL-DFT methods are collected in . All of the N2 adsorption isotherms are a mixture of type I and type II, corresponding to microporous and macroporous/nonporous solids, respectively. Micropore filling occurs in all cases at very low relative pressure. In the case of Zn-Me 2 BPZ and Co-Me 2 BPZ, but mainly for the latter, the isotherms show a small knee at P/P 0 < 0.1, denoting heterogeneity of the micropores (i.e., a wide pore size distribution). After the knee, the isotherms increase linearly and smoothly up to P/P 0 ∼ 0.8. Although this slope can be associated with the presence of mesoporosity, the absence of a significant hysteresis loop during desorption witnesses the absence of a significant porosity in the mesoporous range. With the exception of Zn-BPZ, the slope of the isotherms increases abruptly above P/P 0 > 0.8; this occurrence is due to the presence of larger mesopores and macropores, possibly interparticle voids, and multilayer adsorption processes. The pore size distribution (PSD) obtained by the NL-DFT method (c,d) shows in all cases a very sharp maximum in the micropore region, followed by an irregular distribution of larger pores; a second maximum is detected in the range of large mesopores with diameter of ∼30 nm, which can be associated, as just commented, to interparticle voids. Worthy of note, there is a good agreement () among the values of the parameters provided by the different calculation methods (BET, DR, or DFT) for a given MOF: Similar values of specific surface areas (SSAs) are obtained through the BET or DR equations, as well similar micropore volumes (W 0) through the DR or DFT analysis; however, a clear tendency is not observed on passing from the M-BPZ to the M-Me 2 BPZ series: Indeed, W 0 increases, and consequently the surface area values, for the Co-containing MOFs but decreases in the case of the Zn-based MOFs. On the contrary, the mean micropore width (L 0, ) accessible to N2 in M-BPZ is ∼0.5 nm, while in the case of M-Me 2 BPZ a wider microporosity (L 0 ≈ 0.8 nm) is detected. These features are in very good agreement with those retrieved from the crystal structures (): for Zn-BPZ, the micropore width L 0 = 0.52 nm perfectly fits the dimension of the 1-D channels (0.53 × 0.53 nm2). Similar conclusions can be drawn for Co-Me 2 BPZ and Zn-Me 2 BPZ: the two MOFs show 1-D channels 0.76 × 0.58 and 0.72 × 0.58 nm2 wide, respectively (), to be compared to an average micropore size of 0.79 and 0.77 nm, respectively. These results clearly highlight that, at 77 K, N2 reaches all the available microporosity of the MOFs under investigation and that no breathing or swelling effects are at work. Incidentally, either the shape of the N2-adsorption isotherms or the specific surface area values of the M-BPZ MOFs are consistent with those previously found.

To ascertain the role of the methyl groups, adsorption of the quadrupolar molecule CO2 was investigated at 273 K for M-BPZ and M-Me 2 BPZ. The pertinent adsorption isotherms are collected in , while the results obtained from their analysis are provided in . Incidentally, as these MOFs are eminently microporous, CO2 adsorption helps in complementing the study of their microporosity. It is noteworthy that, in all of the cases, the micropore volume obtained from the N2-adsorption isotherms (W 0(N2)) is smaller than that obtained from CO2-adsorption (W 0(CO2)) ( and , respectively). Typically, while W 0(N2) > W 0(CO2) when N2 condensation occurs upon filling large micropores and mesopores, W 0(N2) < W 0(CO2) when the accessibility of N2 into ultramicropores (<0.7 nm) is limited. Mainly in the case of the M-BPZ couple, the greater W 0 retrieved from the CO2-isotherms cannot be due to a better accessibility of CO2 into narrower micropores, as also L 0 increases on passing from N2 to CO2 (from ∼0.5 to ∼0.9 nm; and , respectively). Nor could the enhanced adsorption toward CO2 be promoted solely by stronger host–guest interactions: the adsorption energy E ads values are smaller for CO2 than for N2 ( and , respectively). To explain that (i) L 0 determined by N2 and CO2 adsorption increases for M-BPZ but not for M-Me 2 BPZ (∼0.7–0.8 nm with both adsorbates) and concomitantly (ii) W 0(CO2) is about two (M-Me 2 BPZ) to four (M-BPZ) times greater than W 0(N2), it can be proposed that N2 probes the microporosity characterizing the ambient conditions crystal structures (see ), while the frameworks undergo structural changes during CO2 adsorption, enhancing the size and/or volume of the micropores. A representative example in this respect is the MOF SNU-9 (Zn2(BPnDC)2(bpy), H2BPnDC = benzophenonedicarboxylic acid), for which Bon and co-workers proposed that the adsorption of CO2 at 195 K and N2 at 77 K proceeds in a different way, and postulated a structural rearrangement during CO2 adsorption. Further significant examples can be found in ref .

In all of the cases, the values of the CO2 adsorption energy () denotes only physisorption processes: indeed, the adsorption capacity of CO2-saturated samples (at atmospheric pressure) is completely recovered by degasifying the samples overnight at 110 °C under a vacuum. All the CO2-isotherms were repeated 2–3 times, being in all cases completely reproducible (; the values in are the mean values retrieved from the consecutive cycles). Worthy of note, there is a slight increase of E ads on passing from M-BPZ to M-Me 2 BPZ (), suggesting slightly stronger host–guest interactions in the case of the CH3-tagged MOFs, as pointed out by recent theoretical studies (see for further comments on this topic). Regrettably, the positive role of the methyl groups in M-Me 2 BPZ, suggested also by theoretical calculations (see ), is hampered by SSA and pore volume reduction () due to their steric hindrance. A valuable example in this respect is the work by Liu and co-workers, who compared the performance of Zn­(BDC)­(DMBPY)0.5 and Zn­(NDC)­(DMBPY)0.5 (H2BDC = 1,4-benzene-dicarboxylic acid, DMBPY = 2,2′-dimethyl-4,4′-bipyridine, H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalene-dicarboxylic acid), as CO2 adsorbents, with that of the nonmethylated isostructural counterparts Zn­(BDC)­(BPY)0.5 and Zn­(NDC)­(BPY)0.5 (BPY = 4,4′-bipyridine). In the case of the NDC-containing couple, the same trend as ours was observed.

elements.content: Finally, at 273 K and 1 bar the amount of reversibly physisorbed CO2 varies between 2.0 and 4.4 mmol/g (). The M-Me 2 BPZ MOFs adsorb 11.4 wt % (M = Co) or 8.8 wt % (M = Zn) at 273 K and 1 bar. The performance of CH3-tagged MOFs as CO2 adsorbents in similar experimental conditions is rather heterogeneous, ranging from 2.0 wt % at 303 K and 1 bar for UiO-66-MM, to 4.0 wt % at 273 K and 1 bar for Zn­(NDC)­(DMBPY)0.5, 8.6 wt % at 298 K and 1 bar for [Zn3(BPDC)3­(3,3′-DMBPY)] (H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid), 11.4 wt % at 273 K and 1 bar for Zn­(BDC)­(DMBPY)0.5, 17.3 wt % at 273 K and 1 bar for Cu3(CMPEIP)2 (H3CMPEIP = 5-[(4-carboxy-2-methylphenyl)­ethynyl]­isophthalic acid).

elements.content: In order to enlighten on the nature and strength of the interactions between the CO2 molecules and the framework of the M-Me 2 BPZ (M = Co, Zn) MOFs, we performed ab initio simulations introducing an increasing amount of CO2 molecules within the channels (1–3 molecules per cell). Recent DFT calculations on CH3-functionalized benzene have proven that the methyl group has a positive inductive effect that strengthens the interaction between CO2 and the aromatic ring: by pumping electron density into the aromatic system, the methyl group increases the interactions between the aromatic system and the molecular quadrupole of CO2. In addition, weak hydrogen bond-like interactions between CO2 and the hydrogen atoms of the methyl group contribute to the stability of the aromatic ring-CO2 system. Periodic DFT calculations on functionalized MOFs have shown that the positive effect of functionalizing benzene with −CH3 is maintained and even enhanced in the solid: as a matter of fact, the calculated binding energy passes from −7.3 kJ/mol for dimethylbenzene to −14.9 kJ/mol in MOFs. On the basis of these evidences we have investigated the interaction of carbon dioxide with the M-Me 2 BPZ MOFs and the parent Zn-BPZ compound. The computational parameters adopted have been detailed in . Preliminary to any study involving host–guest interactions, to figure out possible adsorption sites we calculated the charge density of the M-Me 2 BPZ and Zn-BPZ MOFs. As shown in , positive, although rather shielded regions exist close to the metal ions, whereas negative regions are present around the nitrogen atoms. We then loaded an increasing amount of CO2 molecules in the crystal structures retrieved by PXRD, and evaluated the adsorption energy, E ads, at the B3LYP-D3 level, according to , reported in . At this stage, we adopted the D3 a posteriori correction, as it is claimed to be a high-level method to treat solid–gas phase interactions and weakly bonded compounds characterized by π-conjugated systems. The main results of these calculations are reported in . For the sake of completeness, a geometry (i.e., lattice parameters and atomic positions) optimization was carried out at the B3LYP level, and CO2 adsorption was investigated also into the optimized crystal structures. The pertinent results are shown in . As can be seen by comparing the experimental vs computed unit cell parameters (), upon optimization the crystal structures of the M-Me 2 BPZ and Zn-BPZ MOFs undergo unit cell volume variations of −10% and 6%, respectively, which is reasonably due to the computational method adopted, as already experienced on similar systems. Nonetheless, working with optimized crystal structures enabled us to calculate standard enthalpies and IR spectra (see below).
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Adsorption, a Theoretical Insight

In order to enlighten on the nature and strength of the interactions between the CO2 molecules and the framework of the M-Me  2  BPZ (M = Co, Zn) MOFs, we performed ab initio simulations introducing an increasing amount of CO2 molecules within the channels (1-3 molecules per cell). Recent DFT calculations on CH3-functionalized benzene have proven that the methyl group has a positive inductive effect that strengthens the interaction between CO2 and the aromatic ring: by pumping electron density into the aromatic system, the methyl group increases the interactions between the aromatic system and the molecular quadrupole of CO2. In addition, weak hydrogen bond-like interactions between CO2 and the hydrogen atoms of the methyl group contribute to the stability of the aromatic ring-CO2 system. Periodic DFT calculations on functionalized MOFs have shown that the positive effect of functionalizing benzene with -CH3 is maintained and even enhanced in the solid: as a matter of fact, the calculated binding energy passes from -7.3 kJ/mol for dimethylbenzene to -14.9 kJ/mol in MOFs. On the basis of these evidences we have investigated the interaction of carbon dioxide with the M-Me  2  BPZ MOFs and the parent Zn-BPZ  compound. The computational parameters adopted have been detailed in . Preliminary to any study involving host-guest interactions, to figure out possible adsorption sites we calculated the charge density of the M-Me  2  BPZ and Zn-BPZ MOFs. As shown in , positive, although rather shielded regions exist close to the metal ions, whereas negative regions are present around the nitrogen atoms. We then loaded an increasing amount of CO2 molecules in the crystal structures retrieved by PXRD, and evaluated the adsorption energy, E ads, at the B3LYP-D3 level, according to , reported in . At this stage, we adopted the D3 a posteriori correction, as it is claimed to be a high-level method to treat solid-gas phase interactions and weakly bonded compounds characterized by π-conjugated systems. The main results of these calculations are reported in . For the sake of completeness, a geometry (i.e., lattice parameters and atomic positions) optimization was carried out at the B3LYP level, and CO2 adsorption was investigated also into the optimized crystal structures. The pertinent results are shown in . As can be seen by comparing the experimental vs computed unit cell parameters (), upon optimization the crystal structures of the M-Me  2  BPZ and Zn-BPZ MOFs undergo unit cell volume variations of -10% and 6%, respectively, which is reasonably due to the computational method adopted, as already experienced on similar systems. Nonetheless, working with optimized crystal structures enabled us to calculate standard enthalpies and IR spectra (see below).

Standard enthalpies, H(T), at 0 and 298 K were calculated according to , reported in . The corresponding results, in kJ/mol, are collected in . With reference to this table, irrespective of the fact that CO2 molecules are dosed in the experimental or optimized crystal structures, the trend |E ads(M-Me 2 BPZ)| > |E ads(Zn-BPZ)|, in line with the experimental results (), could be observed, pointing out the key role of the methyl groups in adsorption. Heats of adsorption are in the range of reversible physisorption for all of the investigated MOFs, as pointed out also by the textural characterization. Moreover, as the concentration of CO2 increases, weak attractive interactions between guest molecules almost compensate for short-range repulsions due to hindrance effects. The adsorption energies calculated on the experimental crystal structures () are in rather good agreement with the values retrieved from the adsorption isotherms (); the small overbinding of the adsorption energies and enthalpies calculated on the optimized crystal structures is probably due to the overestimation of dispersive terms, as evaluated by the a posteriori correction.

elements.content:
The IR spectra () calculated on the optimized crystal structures confirm both the sensitive implication of the methyl groups and the interactions of CO2 with the channel walls via quadrupolar-π electron density interactions. As can be seen in a, comparing the IR spectrum of nCO2@Zn-Me 2 BPZ with that of empty Zn-Me 2 BPZ, the −CH3 stretching modes, active in the region between 3300 and 3000 cm–1, are strongly perturbed by gas uptake. Moreover, the bands due to bending and asymmetric stretching of CO2, that in the gas phase are calculated to be at 686 and 2592 cm–1, respectively, are significantly lowered and split in several bands due to host–guest interactions, as reported b,c. Calculated binding energies and spectral fingerprint are the resultant of several different processes occurring inside the channels. To single out the various effects, we have analyzed the bonding framework performing an accurate topological analysis of the electron density. Irrespective of the fact that the topological analysis is carried out on the experimental or optimized crystal structures, the emerging frame is the same, namely:

the driving forces for adsorption are (i) hydrogen bonds between the oxygen atoms of the guest molecules and the hydrogen atoms of the methyl groups, and (ii) weak multipolar interactions occurring between the carbon and nitrogen atoms of the ligand with CO2;

as already unveiled by the crystal structures and the analysis of the charge density, the Co­(II) and Zn­(II) ions are shielded and totally inactive toward CO2;

guest–guest attractive interactions are at work, at least up to a concentration of 3 CO2 molecules per cell;

Moreover, the bands due to bending and asymmetric stretching of CO2, that in the gas phase are calculated to be at 686 and 2592 cm-1, respectively, are significantly lowered and split in several bands due to host-guest interactions, as reported b,c. Calculated binding energies and spectral fingerprint are the resultant of several different processes occurring inside the channels. To single out the various effects, we have analyzed the bonding framework performing an accurate topological analysis of the electron density. Irrespective of the fact that the topological analysis is carried out on the experimental or optimized crystal structures, the emerging frame is the same, namely:  (a) the driving forces for adsorption are (i) hydrogen bonds between the oxygen atoms of the guest molecules and the hydrogen atoms of the methyl groups, and (ii) weak multipolar interactions occurring between the carbon and nitrogen atoms of the ligand with CO2;   (b) as already unveiled by the crystal structures and the analysis of the charge density, the Co(II) and Zn(II) ions are shielded and totally inactive toward CO2;   (c) guest-guest attractive interactions are at work, at least up to a concentration of 3 CO2 molecules per cell;

Temperature effects, which have been estimated taking into account the lattice phonon spectrum, are negligible, and then, in agreement with the experimental evidence, CO2 uptake is favored also at room temperature.

The novel coordination polymers M­(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2Me2BPZ = 3,3′-dimethyl-1H,1′H-4,4′-bipyrazole), M­(H2Me2BPZ)­(CH3COO)2­(H2O)2 (M = Co, Ni), and Cu­(H2Me2BPZ)­(Cl)2 were isolated in the form of microcrystalline powders and characterized as for their crystal structure and thermal stability by powder X-ray diffraction. The textural properties of the two MOFs M-Me 2 BPZ (M = Co, Zn), featuring 3-D open frameworks with 1-D channels, were studied by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively, and compared to those of the nonmethylated counterparts M-BPZ: The positive effect of the methyl groups in CO2 adsorption was suggested by the adsorption energy trend E ads(M-Me 2 BPZ, CO2) > E ads(M-BPZ, CO2) and corroborated by ab initio calculations at the B3LYP-D3 level coupled to a topological analysis. Additionally, for both series the increase of the micropore volume concomitant to the decrease of the adsorption energy on passing from N2 to CO2 suggested a different adsorption path for the two gases, with a structural deformation possibly characterizing that for CO2. The advantageous functionalization of the ligand is somehow hindered by the higher steric hindrance of Me2BPZ2– vs BPZ2–: Hence, the MOFs M-Me 2 BPZ represent an interesting case study, but more work should be carried out to further investigate CH3-tagging for CO2 adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The novel coordination polymers M(Me2BPZ) (M = Co, Zn; H2Me2BPZ = 3,3'-dimethyl-1H,1'H-4,4'-bipyrazole), M(H2Me2BPZ)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2 (M = Co, Ni), and Cu(H2Me2BPZ)(Cl)2 were isolated in the form of microcrystalline powders and characterized as for their crystal structure and thermal stability by powder X-ray diffraction. The textural properties of the two MOFs M-Me  2  BPZ (M = Co, Zn), featuring 3-D open frameworks with 1-D channels, were studied by N2 and CO2 adsorption at 77 and 273 K, respectively, and compared to those of the nonmethylated counterparts M-BPZ: The positive effect of the methyl groups in CO2 adsorption was suggested by the adsorption energy trend E ads(M-Me  2  BPZ, CO2) > E ads(M-BPZ, CO2) and corroborated by ab initio calculations at the B3LYP-D3 level coupled to a topological analysis. Additionally, for both series the increase of the micropore volume concomitant to the decrease of the adsorption energy on passing from N2 to CO2 suggested a different adsorption path for the two gases, with a structural deformation possibly characterizing that for CO2. The advantageous functionalization of the ligand is somehow hindered by the higher steric hindrance of Me2BPZ2- vs BPZ2-: Hence, the MOFs M-Me  2  BPZ represent an interesting case study, but more work should be carried out to further investigate CH3-tagging for CO2 adsorption.

elements.content: The advantage of N2 adsorption is that it covers relative pressures in the range 10–8 to 1, which allows probing the whole range of porosity of a material. The main disadvantage of N2 adsorption at 77 K when used for the characterization of microporous solids is that diffusional problems of the probe molecules inside the narrow porosity range may occur. To fix this issue, the use of other adsorbates has been proposed. At 273 K, the saturation pressure of CO2 is ∼35 bar. Thus, for typical CO2 adsorption equipment with a maximum achievable pressure of 1 bar, the maximum relative pressure is P/P 0 ≈ 3 × 10–2. In these experimental conditions diffusion problems are considerably reduced and pores as small as 0.4 nm can be accessed. In the light of this, CO2 adsorption has been proposed to be complementary to N2 adsorption for the analysis of textural porosity, as it can be used to assess the narrower microporosity (L 0 < 0.7 nm), where N2 adsorption can be kinetically restricted.

H2Me2BPZ (0.0324 g, 0.200 mmol) was dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF) (8 mL). Then, Co­(CH3COO)2­·4H2O (0.0498 g, 0.200 mmol) was added. The mixture was left under stirring in a high-pressure glass tube at 120 °C for 24 h, until a violet precipitate appeared. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with hot acetone (2 × 10 mL), and dried under vacuum. Yield: 86%. Co-BPZ was synthesized following a previously published synthetic methodology, namely, H2BPZ (0.0268 g, 0.200 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (15 mL). CCDC No. 1526566.

Thermal BehaviorThermal Behavior of <bold>Co-Me</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>BPZ·S</bold> and <bold>Zn-Me</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>BPZ·S.</bold>

According to their TGA traces (), the two compounds M-Me 2 BPZ·S (M = Co, Zn) are stable, under N2, up to ∼340 and 460 °C, respectively. Loss of clathrated solvent is denounced, below 200 °C, by weight losses of ∼24% and ∼23%, corresponding to ∼1 and ∼0.9 mol of DMF per formula unit (f.u.) for Co-Me 2 BPZ·S and Zn-Me 2 BPZ·S, respectively (calculated losses 25.0 and 24.4%, respectively). As assessed by in situ and operando VT-PXRD (a,b), solvent loss is not accompanied by loss of crystallinity. As highlighted by a Le Bail parametric treatment of the data (c,d), solvent loss brings about a unit cell volume shrinkage in both compounds. However, the variation in volume has a different trend in the two cases. Zn-Me 2 BPZ shows a step-like decrease of ∼0.8% between 130 and 210 °C, mainly related with the shrinkage of the c-axis. On the other hand, Co-Me 2 BPZ shows a smooth decrease of ∼ −1.3% in the temperature range 30–330 °C, related with the decrease of the b- and c-axes. Above 350 °C, both compounds start suffering from loss of crystallinity.

Thermal Behavior of <bold>Co-H</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>Me</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>BPZ</bold> and <bold>Ni-H</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>Me</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>BPZ</bold>

According to their TGA traces (), the two compounds M-H 2 Me 2 BPZ are stable, under N2, only up to ∼125 °C (M = Co) and 70 °C (M = Ni). The ∼30% weight loss observed in the TGA trace of Co-H 2 Me 2 BPZ in the temperature range 125–175 °C is in agreement with the release of two molecules of acetic acid per f.u. (theoretical loss 32%). The weight loss of ∼10% observed in the range 200–400 °C can be assigned to the loss of two molecules of water per f.u. (theoretical loss 9.6%). Ni-H 2 Me 2 BPZ undergoes three consecutive mass losses, namely, 10% (70–150 °C), 20% (150–250 °C), and 10% (250–400 °C), overall corresponding to the loss of two molecules of acetic acid and two molecules of water per f.u. (theoretical loss 41.6%). VT-PXRD (Figure S3a,b of the SI) confirms the limited thermal robustness of the two materials and highlights that no phase change takes place before the first weight loss, which is accompanied by loss of crystallinity (observed starting from 150 °C for both compounds). A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data before loss of crystallinity enabled us to highlight that while the a- and c-axes undergo negligible variations in the temperature range 30–150 °C (Figure S3c,d of the SI), the b-axis is affected by a slightly higher variation, increasing by 0.8%, with a concomitant increase of the unit cell volume amounting to 0.8% (M = Co) or 0.9% (M = Ni) in the same temperature range. The slight increase of the b-axis is reasonably promoted by a weakening of the interchain hydrogen bond interactions existing, at room temperature, along the [010] direction (b). At least in the conditions essayed for the VT-PXRD experiments, loss of coordinated acetic acid and water molecules does not bring about the formation of microcrystalline homoleptic compounds of formula M­(Me2BPZ), as observed in the past for Zn­(CH3COO)­(pz)­(Hpz).

Thermal Behavior of <bold>Cu-H</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>Me</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>BPZ</bold>

According to its TGA trace () Cu-H 2 Me 2 BPZ decomposes starting from ∼280 °C. VT-PXRD (Figure S4a in the SI) confirms this evidence also in air and highlights that no phase change takes place before loss of crystallinity is observed (∼330 °C). A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data reveals (Figure S4b in the SI) that the unit cell axis undergoing the highest variation is the a-axis (increasing by 2.2% in the temperature range 30–330 °C), this occurrence suggesting a weakening of the π–π interactions along the [100] direction (a). Because of thermal expansion, the unit cell volume increases by 2.3%.

A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data before loss of crystallinity enabled us to highlight that while the a- and c-axes undergo negligible variations in the temperature range 30-150 °C (Figure S3c,d of the SI), the b-axis is affected by a slightly higher variation, increasing by 0.8%, with a concomitant increase of the unit cell volume amounting to 0.8% (M = Co) or 0.9% (M = Ni) in the same temperature range. The slight increase of the b-axis is reasonably promoted by a weakening of the interchain hydrogen bond interactions existing, at room temperature, along the [010] direction (b). At least in the conditions essayed for the VT-PXRD experiments, loss of coordinated acetic acid and water molecules does not bring about the formation of microcrystalline homoleptic compounds of formula M(Me2BPZ), as observed in the past for Zn(CH3COO)(pz)(Hpz). 

Thermal Behavior of Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ 

According to its TGA trace () Cu-H  2  Me  2  BPZ decomposes starting from ~280 °C. VT-PXRD (Figure S4a in the SI) confirms this evidence also in air and highlights that no phase change takes place before loss of crystallinity is observed (~330 °C). A Le Bail parametric treatment of the data reveals (Figure S4b in the SI) that the unit cell axis undergoing the highest variation is the a-axis (increasing by 2.2% in the temperature range 30-330 °C), this occurrence suggesting a weakening of the π-π interactions along the [100] direction (a). Because of thermal expansion, the unit cell volume increases by 2.3%.

cln_elements.content: Finally, at 273 K and 1 bar the amount of reversibly physisorbed CO2 varies between 2.0 and 4.4 mmol/g (). The M-Me 2 BPZ MOFs adsorb 11.4 wt % (M = Co) or 8.8 wt % (M = Zn) at 273 K and 1 bar. The performance of CH3-tagged MOFs as CO2 adsorbents in similar experimental conditions is rather heterogeneous, ranging from 2.0 wt % at 303 K and 1 bar for UiO-66-MM, to 4.0 wt % at 273 K and 1 bar for Zn­(NDC)­(DMBPY)0.5, 8.6 wt % at 298 K and 1 bar for [Zn3(BPDC)3­(3,3′-DMBPY)] (H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid), 11.4 wt % at 273 K and 1 bar for Zn­(BDC)­(DMBPY)0.5, 17.3 wt % at 273 K and 1 bar for Cu3(CMPEIP)2 (H3CMPEIP = 5-[(4-carboxy-2-methylphenyl)­ethynyl]­isophthalic acid).
